Tickets for the Rutgers

night, March 11, were put on

The prices are $1.50 a couple
and $1.00 stag.

team will depend on the financial sucess of this meet.
Tickets may be obtained
from Stone, Armour, Dalse:tier or Ghent, which will also
include the dance which will
follow the meet.

R. BRENT KEYSER
Hopkins, together with all Baltimore, mourns Mr. R. Brent
Keyser as a man and a citizen, but it is as a member of the board
of trustees, of which he was president for a period of twenty-three
years, that his loss is especially felt by the University.
It is difficult, in this column usually given over to the trivialities of everyday life on the campus, to adequately express the
sorrow of the University at the death of such a man as Mr. Keyser.
There is so much risk of blundering,. of attempting to say only
the obvious thing.
These misgivings, however, cannot prevent us from expressing the feeling of the undergraduates of Hopkins at the passing
of a man who for so many years had the interests of the University at heart, and who accomplished so much for it. Mr. Keyser
will be remembered as a leader of the University, and as one of
its greatest benefactors.
As president of the board of trustees, he gave twenty-three
years of constructive service. His greatest single achievement in
this period was the removal of the University to Homewood, a
movement in which he was the leader, and which was brought
about largely through his efforts. At the time of his death, although no longer president, he was still an active member of the
board of trustees.

A certain interesting book entitled "The Mind in the Making"
devoted considerable space' to the discussion of revery, that sort
of thinking common to everyone, but seldom mentioned because of
its remarkable scope; it is remembered, if at all, with a sort of
shyness and wonder. Revery has never been employed as a literary medium,—at least, as far as I know. The following is a
cross-section of thought which anyone might claim. It begins
at 7:40 any morning.
* * * *
What? . . . Yes . . . yes . . . in a minute ;—why right now . . .
I should get up; no, I shouldn't, but I must. I won't. Somehow
I am perfectly right in lying here; by doing so I assert my rights
over... over.. over ...
Yes!—The shock of getting up is subtly hateful. . . Cold
water is like a conscience, somehow. Satisfactory self-discipline.
And I need a new neck-tie. How many steps are there in this
flight. I'll count them sometime. Four—and four—then an odd
number—I land with consummate grace.
I can't understand why I smile. You look sleepy, pa. I
don't feel polite. I am not polite; I'm only pretending to be; why?
. . S'long.
She is not there, and looking for her has gotten to be a habit,
anyway. Not that I care particularly—there's ice here; I'll slide—
a gorgeous sensation, in which there is an undefined freedom; you
seem to let go of everything.—What is his face like? He must
drink, if bleary blue wishy-washy eyes mean anything. If I had a
million dollars I'd have a camp in Maine and let everybody come
free. Somebody could take charge of all the practical duties.
Horses. I'd look better on a horse than anywhere else—if the
horse remained stationary. Did Napoleon ride a horse? He
should have. Don't look at me that way, girl. What are you
thinking about? What do other people think about? Do their
minds ramble on like this? She was a shop-girl. They probably
think, too ... or do they?
This is the same bus. The driver's face looks as if he had
been of a sweet disposition until his wife had poisoned his pet dog.
Some day I'll climb these steps without touching the rail. I believe I smoke on the bus-top just because it is permitted. Hello.
Got change for this? Of course he has change. They always
have. No, not so cold. Where are those twins. If I ever miss
seeing those twins and smiling satisfied at their detailed identity,
I think I'll go home immediately. There you are. Thank God.
I can't tell them apart. Thank God. . . . I'm going to be late.
I'm always late. How late today? Apollo Belvedere looks like a
nigger this morning, because his body is all shiny black. In dry
weather he is a bilious green. What makes iron get that way?
Oh I must walk on this grass. Each blade is sheathed in ice.
Fascinating sound—like chewing celery.—Not bad, if it's original.
I don't care; I'll repeat it. Not very late. Wish to God he
wouldn't stop talking every time I come in late. Now fire away...
Those are words. What are words, anyway? Remarkable creations behind which we conceal ourselves—imperfectly. . . . Like
a bee droning—uncomfortable seat. . . . Like a distant buzz saw
... words .. . droning.
* * * *
The idea of a course in auction bridge should be introduced
to those who construct the curriculum. It would begin with a
required course for freshmen—bridge of sighs, I guess; these
required courses are always tiresome. Hands could be worked out
on the black-board.... And for Latin student, "Pons Assinorum"
... a more advanced course, including high-low bidding, two-card
finesses, no trump take-outs, and informatory doubling. . . .
Eventually we might install enough courses to have one conducted
in French ;—Pont Neuf, it might be. It would be intensely interesting to set Dr. French on a one-club bid, or to hand shake Dr.
Turner by allowing him a slam you could easily have prevented.
... And why not? Why not admit that college life is a luxurious
waste of time, and make the most of it? Of course, for practical
minded, coarse and uncultured engineers "civil" bridge would of
necessity substitute for the less gallant civil bridge-building.

term as head of the trustees, were probably of equal, if not greater
value. Hopkins owes much to this man of such great prominence
in the community, and with so many other interests, who willingly
gave his time and his ability in the interests of the University.
Mr. Keyser is mourned not only by the men of Hopkins who
knew him personally, but also by the great mass of students to
whom he was a name and an ideal. To such men, and they have
been all too few, the University is indebted for its strength. In
his death Hopkins has suffered an inestimable loss.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 4, 1927
DR. HANFORD OF MICHIGAN
TO SPEAK HERE

FRESHMAN TANK SQUAD FALLS
BEFORE CRACK POLYTECHNIC FISH

Will Deliver Fifth Annual Tudor and
Stuart Club Lecture

Hopkins' freshman swimming
team got off to a poor start last
Tuesday when they lost their first
meet of the season ,to Baltimore
Polytechnic at the Knights of Columbus pool. The prep natators
took first place in every event except one, bringing their total to
Fifty-one against seventeen for the
freshmen.
Things began to look dark for
the yearlings right from the start
when Baum and Kirby of Poly

James Holly Hanford, Professor
of English at the University of
Michigan, will be the speaker at the
fifth annual lecture held under the
auspices of the Tudor and Stuart
Club. Professor Hanford will lecture on "Creative Personality: The
Case of Milton," on March 11, at
5 P. M., in the Civil Engineering
Hall. The talk will be open to the
public and no admission will be
charged.
The occasion marks the fifth successive year that a person of literary
fame has been brought by the Tudor
and Stuart Club to Johns Hopkins
to speak before the undergraduates.
Such celebrated poets as Robert
Frost and M. Cestre were among
those selected to deliver the annual
Tudor and Stuart Club lecture. Two
years ago Dr. Edwin Greenlaw, now
a member of the Hopkins faculty
and the Tudor and Stuart Club, was
the speaker.
Professor Hanford, a man of national note, will be entertained on
the evening of the same day at an informal dinner to be given in his
honor at the Alumni Memorial Dormitories. This was made possible
by the courtesy of Mrs. Vanneman,
who offered the Dormitory for the
occasion.
The dinner will begin at 7:30
P. M. but is closed to al but members of the Tudor and Stuart Club.

In the "Travel Number" of The
Black and Blue Jay which will appear this Monday, may be observed
a rather favorable comparison with
veteran travel numbers of other
college comics, although this will be
the Jay's first attempt at such a
number.
Steamship lines, various European chambers of commerce, and
many companies which supply the
needs of the world traveler have cooperated by means of advertisements
to make this first travel Jay a success
financially. Mathews,Hurwitz,Chapman, Banks, and Reese have contributed a number of drawings to
make it a success artistically. The
romance language and Greek departments have also contributed its
bit to make the Jay editorially different in the field of American
humor.

College Comics Meeting

At the meeting of the Association of College Comics of the East
which will be held tomorrow and
Sunday in Philadelphia, The Black
and Blue Jay, which has long been
dissatisfied with the existing state
of affairs in the Association, will
bring up the principal questions to
be discussed, those of the rate of
discount to be allowed to advertising
agencies, of granting College
Humor exclusive reprint privileges,
and of releasing college humorous
material to syndicates for daily and
weekly release.
The seven men who will represent the Jay will travel by train, or
by automobile to Philadelphia. They
will leave Baltimore tonight, with
the exception of Maxwell Cone, who
will leave this afternoon to attend
a special preliminary meeting of
the more important representatives.

follow the meet.

R. BRENT KEYSER
Hopkins, together with all Baltimore, mourns Mr. R. Brent
Keyser as a man and a citizen, but it is as a member of the board
of trustees, of which he was president for a period of twenty-three
years, that his loss is especially felt by the University.
It is difficult, in this column usually given over to the trivialities of everyday life on the campus, to adequately express the
sorrow of the University at the death of such a man as Mr. Keyser.
There is so much risk of blundering,. of attempting to say only
the obvious thing.
These misgivings, however, cannot prevent us from expressing the feeling of the undergraduates of Hopkins at the passing
of a man who for so many years had the interests of the University at heart, and who accomplished so much for it. Mr. Keyser
will be remembered as a leader of the University, and as one of
its greatest benefactors.
As president of the board of trustees, he gave twenty-three
years of constructive service. His greatest single achievement in
this period was the removal of the University to Homewood, a
movement in which he was the leader, and which was brought
about largely through his efforts. At the time of his death, although no longer president, he was still an active member of the
board of trustees.

A certain interesting book entitled "The Mind in the Making"
devoted considerable space' to the discussion of revery, that sort
of thinking common to everyone, but seldom mentioned because of
its remarkable scope; it is remembered, if at all, with a sort of
shyness and wonder. Revery has never been employed as a literary medium,—at least, as far as I know. The following is a
cross-section of thought which anyone might claim. It begins
at 7:40 any morning.
* * * *
What? . . . Yes . . . yes . . . in a minute ;—why right now . . .
I should get up; no, I shouldn't, but I must. I won't. Somehow
I am perfectly right in lying here; by doing so I assert my rights
over... over.. over ...
Yes!—The shock of getting up is subtly hateful. . . Cold
water is like a conscience, somehow. Satisfactory self-discipline.
And I need a new neck-tie. How many steps are there in this
flight. I'll count them sometime. Four—and four—then an odd
number—I land with consummate grace.
I can't understand why I smile. You look sleepy, pa. I
don't feel polite. I am not polite; I'm only pretending to be; why?
. . S'long.
She is not there, and looking for her has gotten to be a habit,
anyway. Not that I care particularly—there's ice here; I'll slide—
a gorgeous sensation, in which there is an undefined freedom; you
seem to let go of everything.—What is his face like? He must
drink, if bleary blue wishy-washy eyes mean anything. If I had a
million dollars I'd have a camp in Maine and let everybody come
free. Somebody could take charge of all the practical duties.
Horses. I'd look better on a horse than anywhere else—if the
horse remained stationary. Did Napoleon ride a horse? He
should have. Don't look at me that way, girl. What are you
thinking about? What do other people think about? Do their
minds ramble on like this? She was a shop-girl. They probably
think, too ... or do they?
This is the same bus. The driver's face looks as if he had
been of a sweet disposition until his wife had poisoned his pet dog.
Some day I'll climb these steps without touching the rail. I believe I smoke on the bus-top just because it is permitted. Hello.
Got change for this? Of course he has change. They always
have. No, not so cold. Where are those twins. If I ever miss
seeing those twins and smiling satisfied at their detailed identity,
I think I'll go home immediately. There you are. Thank God.
I can't tell them apart. Thank God. . . . I'm going to be late.
I'm always late. How late today? Apollo Belvedere looks like a
nigger this morning, because his body is all shiny black. In dry
weather he is a bilious green. What makes iron get that way?
Oh I must walk on this grass. Each blade is sheathed in ice.
Fascinating sound—like chewing celery.—Not bad, if it's original.
I don't care; I'll repeat it. Not very late. Wish to God he
wouldn't stop talking every time I come in late. Now fire away...
Those are words. What are words, anyway? Remarkable creations behind which we conceal ourselves—imperfectly. . . . Like
a bee droning—uncomfortable seat. . . . Like a distant buzz saw
... words .. . droning.
* * * *
The idea of a course in auction bridge should be introduced
to those who construct the curriculum. It would begin with a
required course for freshmen—bridge of sighs, I guess; these
required courses are always tiresome. Hands could be worked out
on the black-board.... And for Latin student, "Pons Assinorum"
... a more advanced course, including high-low bidding, two-card
finesses, no trump take-outs, and informatory doubling. . . .
Eventually we might install enough courses to have one conducted
in French ;—Pont Neuf, it might be. It would be intensely interesting to set Dr. French on a one-club bid, or to hand shake Dr.
Turner by allowing him a slam you could easily have prevented.
... And why not? Why not admit that college life is a luxurious
waste of time, and make the most of it? Of course, for practical
minded, coarse and uncultured engineers "civil" bridge would of
necessity substitute for the less gallant civil bridge-building.

DR. HANFORD OF MICHIGAN
TO SPEAK HERE

FRESHMAN TANK SQUAD FALLS
BEFORE CRACK POLYTECHNIC FISH

Will Deliver Fifth Annual Tudor and
Stuart Club Lecture

Hopkins' freshman swimming
team got off to a poor start last
Tuesday when they lost their first
meet of the season ,to Baltimore
Polytechnic at the Knights of Columbus pool. The prep natators
took first place in every event except one, bringing their total to
Fifty-one against seventeen for the
freshmen.
Things began to look dark for
the yearlings right from the start
when Baum and Kirby of Poly

James Holly Hanford, Professor
of English at the University of
Michigan, will be the speaker at the
fifth annual lecture held under the
auspices of the Tudor and Stuart
Club. Professor Hanford will lecture on "Creative Personality: The
Case of Milton," on March 11, at
5 P. M., in the Civil Engineering
Hall. The talk will be open to the
public and no admission will be
charged.
The occasion marks the fifth successive year that a person of literary
fame has been brought by the Tudor
and Stuart Club to Johns Hopkins
to speak before the undergraduates.
Such celebrated poets as Robert
Frost and M. Cestre were among
those selected to deliver the annual
Tudor and Stuart Club lecture. Two
years ago Dr. Edwin Greenlaw, now
a member of the Hopkins faculty
and the Tudor and Stuart Club, was
the speaker.
Professor Hanford, a man of national note, will be entertained on
the evening of the same day at an informal dinner to be given in his
honor at the Alumni Memorial Dormitories. This was made possible
by the courtesy of Mrs. Vanneman,
who offered the Dormitory for the
occasion.
The dinner will begin at 7:30
P. M. but is closed to al but members of the Tudor and Stuart Club.

College Comics Meeting

At the meeting of the Association of College Comics of the East
which will be held tomorrow and
Sunday in Philadelphia, The Black
and Blue Jay, which has long been
dissatisfied with the existing state
of affairs in the Association, will
bring up the principal questions to
be discussed, those of the rate of
discount to be allowed to advertising
agencies, of granting College
Humor exclusive reprint privileges,
and of releasing college humorous
material to syndicates for daily and
weekly release.
The seven men who will represent the Jay will travel by train, or
by automobile to Philadelphia. They
will leave Baltimore tonight, with
the exception of Maxwell Cone, who
will leave this afternoon to attend
a special preliminary meeting of
the more important representatives.
